In his experiment, Rosenthal demonstrated that when teachers were led to believe that certain students were expected to perform better academically, those students indeed showed significant improvement.  The study highlighted the influence of teacher expectations on student performance.  The mechanism behind the Rosenthal Effect involves subtle changes in teacher behavior.  Teachers may provide more attention, feedback, and encouragement to students they expect to excel.  This positive reinforcement fosters a supportive learning environment, which can enhance student confidence and motivation.  Consequently, students internalize these expectations and perform in ways that align with them.  The implications of the Rosenthal Effect extend beyond education.
